title: Second Highest Salary
markdown:
# **Second Highest Salary**

**Difficulty:** Medium  •  **Tags:** `SELECT` • `SUBQUERY` • `MAX`



## **Problem Description**

Write a SQL query to get the second highest salary from the `employees` table. Return NULL if there is no second highest.



## **Table Schema**

**employees**
```
+--------+------+
| Column | Type |
+--------+------+
| id     | INT  |
| name   | TEXT |
| salary | INT  |
+--------+------+
```



## **Example**

### **Input**

**employees**
```
+----+---------+--------+
| id | name    | salary |
+----+---------+--------+
| 1  | Alice   | 100000 |
| 2  | Bob     | 80000  |
| 3  | Charlie | 120000 |
+----+---------+--------+
```

### **Expected Output**

```
+---------------------+
| SecondHighestSalary |
+---------------------+
| 100000              |
+---------------------+
```

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE employees(id INT, name TEXT, salary INT); INSERT INTO employees VALUES (1,'Alice',100000),(2,'Bob',80000),(3,'Charlie',120000);
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT MAX(salary) as SecondHighestSalary FROM employees WHERE salary < (SELECT MAX(salary) FROM employees);

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE employees(id INT, name TEXT, salary INT);
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT MAX(salary) as SecondHighestSalary FROM employees WHERE salary < (SELECT MAX(salary) FROM employees);

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE employees(id INT, name TEXT, salary INT); INSERT INTO employees VALUES (1,'Alice',100000),(2,'Bob',80000),(3,'Charlie',120000);
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT MAX(salary) as SecondHighestSalary FROM employees WHERE salary < (SELECT MAX(salary) FROM employees);
